To infer "The train might be on time or late," we need to consider the logical implications of the original statement. If the train might be late, then it means that it is either late or not late (on time). Therefore, the two possibilities that cover all cases are "on time" and "late."

By the principle of logical reasoning, if one possibility (being late) is stated, then the other possibility (being on time) is implied to make the statement logically complete and exhaustive.
